awd_titl_txt: STTR Phase II:  Novel real-time particulate matter (PM) sensor for air quality measurements
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this STTR project is in the reduction of healthcare-associated infections (HAIs) by proactively responding to data from novel sensors.  In addition, the technology being developed in this project can also help measure airborne particle concentrations in other environments.  The successful completion of this proposal will result in improved public health from reduced hospital stay and commercially benefit both hospitals and patients by reducing hospitalization costs.  The development and deployment of sensors in a hospital, enabled by this project, will help our startup build a critical dataset to train analytical models for near real-time identification of hospital spaces with a pathogen problem.

This STTR Phase 2 project proposes to develop a novel sensor for integrated measurement of air quality (AQ) and pathogen loads in the air and combine these measurements to create a an early warning system to identify contaminated areas in critical facilities like hospitals.  Healthcare-associated infections (HAIs) are $20 billion problem and are responsible for over 100,000 deaths in the US.  Our low-cost, robust, networkable, and easy-to-operate sensors will provide a data driven solution to the critical public health problem.  Combining novel techniques for real-time detection of airborne particles with state-of-the-art pathogen analysis, our sensor system will provide data to develop analytical models that will predict hospital spaces with pathogen problems before they cause expensive infections.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
The overarching goal of this project was to develop a compact aerosol sensor integrated with a bioaerosol collector so as to monitor and understand the spatiotemporal variations of airborne microbes in indoor spaces.  As part of this project, we built upon the product development in NSF STTR I project and built the Trio (or Trac-B) unit to provide real-time measurements of airborne particle concentrations and captures particles by electrostatic precipitation for offline analysis.  The device was built to be compact, low-cost, and portable.  Using this device, we monitored air in a hospital to understand the transmission and dispersal of pathogens causing healthcare-associated infections (HAIs). The devices were deployed in five different indoor locations of relevance (emergency, outdoor, operation theater, and two medical-surgical units), and bioaerosol samples captured by the device were collected periodically for analysis using next-generation sequencing. Analysis of samples from the Trio helped us understand that the temporal variation in bacterial and fungal compositions was more pronounced than the spatial variations at any given time point. Our findings suggest that microbial load in the air is higher in the summer and lower in the winter, although the relationship with airborne particle concentration was not straight-forward. Deploying the device in university dorms during the COVID-19 pandemic, we found that the device was successful in capturing SARS-CoV-2 from the air and the estimated viral load corroborated well with the reported active cases. Together, these findings demonstrate that our device is easy to deploy in a variety of indoor locations and is capable of monitoring airborne microbes of a wide size range.  


Last Modified: 07/17/2022
Modified by: R Vijayakumar

As part of this project, we built upon the product development in NSF STTR I project and built the Trio (or Trac-B) unit to provide real-time measurements of airborne particle concentrations and captures particles by electrostatic precipitation for offline analysis.  The device was built to be compact, low-cost, and portable.
